<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 675, 89]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will investigate the balancing of a metre rule. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 576, 121]]<|/det|> Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 158, 880, 288]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 313, 532, 331]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 345, 144, 363]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 375, 636, 393]]<|/det|> · Place the metre rule on the pivot at the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 406, 781, 425]]<|/det|> · Place the object Q with its centre on the metre rule at the 90.0 cm mark. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 438, 608, 456]]<|/det|> · Place a load of weight \(P = 2.0 \text{N}\) on the metre rule. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 469, 918, 503]]<|/det|> · Adjust the position of the load so that the metre rule is as near as possible to being balanced and horizontal. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 516, 180, 534]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 515, 915, 534]]<|/det|> Measure, and record in Table 1.1, the distance \(\mathbf{x}\) from the centre of the load to the pivot. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 546, 917, 565]]<|/det|> Record also the weight of the load. [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 577, 180, 596]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 574, 615, 597]]<|/det|> Calculate, and record in Table 1.1, the value of \(\frac{1}{x}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 577, 917, 596]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 607, 178, 625]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 606, 920, 650]]<|/det|> Repeat the steps above, using loads of weight \(P = 3.0 \text{N}\), \(4.0 \text{N}\), \(5.0 \text{N}\) and \(6.0 \text{N}\). Record all the values of \(P\), \(x\) and \(\frac{1}{x}\) in Table 1.1. [3] <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 660, 539, 679]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[292, 692, 702, 880]]<|/det|>
\(P/\mathrm {N}\)\(x/\mathrm {cm}\)\(\frac {1}{x}/\frac {1}{\mathrm {cm}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 85, 148, 104]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 78, 865, 112]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(P / \mathsf{N}\) (y-axis) against \(\frac{1}{\mathsf{x}} /\frac{1}{\mathsf{cm}}\) (x-axis). Start both axes at the origin (0,0).

<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 521, 860, 555]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, \(x_{\mathrm{max}}\), the maximum possible value for \(x\) is \(50.0 \text{cm}\). Calculate \(\frac{1}{x_{\mathrm{max}}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 579, 920, 616]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\frac{1}{x_{\mathrm{max}}} =\) .................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 634, 920, 670]]<|/det|>
Use the graph to determine the minimum value of \(P\) required to balance the metre rule in this experiment. Show clearly on the graph how you determined this value.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 707, 91]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will determine the resistances of filament lamps.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 576, 121]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[267, 131, 752, 336]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 355, 532, 375]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 388, 144, 407]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 388, 245, 407]]<|/det|>
Switch on.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 419, 181, 437]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 419, 494, 438]]<|/det|>
Measure the current \(I_{1}\) in the circuit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[571, 448, 920, 470]]<|/det|>
<form>\(I_{1} =\) .................................................. A [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 481, 181, 500]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 481, 621, 500]]<|/det|>
Measure the potential difference \(V_{1}\) across lamp \(\mathsf{L}_{1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[567, 510, 920, 532]]<|/det|>
<form>\(V_{1} =\) .................................................. V [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 542, 282, 561]]<|/det|>
Switch off.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 574, 178, 593]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 571, 920, 610]]<|/det|>
Calculate the resistance \(R_{1}\) of the filament of lamp \(\mathsf{L}_{1}\). Use the equation \(R_{1} = \frac{V_{1}}{I_{1}}\). Include the unit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[564, 701, 920, 721]]<|/det|>
<form>\(R_{1} =\) .................................................. [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 732, 91]]<|/det|>
Some students make suggestions about the results of the experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 606, 122]]<|/det|>
Suggestion \(\mathbf{A}\colon R_{1} + R_{2} + R_{3}\) should be equal to \(3\times R_{1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 615, 152]]<|/det|>
Suggestion \(\mathbf{B}\colon R_{1} + R_{2} + R_{3}\) should be less than \(3\times R_{1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 640, 183]]<|/det|>
Suggestion \(\mathbf{C}\colon R_{1} + R_{2} + R_{3}\) should be greater than \(3\times R_{1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 195, 918, 229]]<|/det|>
State which suggestion, \(\mathbf{A}\), \(\mathbf{B}\) or \(\mathbf{C}\), agrees with your results. Justify your answer by reference to your results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 242, 405, 260]]<|/det|>
statement ..............................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 272, 917, 290]]<|/det|>
justification ...................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 319, 920, 338]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 350, 141, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 350, 920, 384]]<|/det|>
A student investigates whether the statement in (e) is always true for the same three lamps connected in series.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 381, 920, 414]]<|/det|>
State a variable that he changes and how he changes the variable. You are **not** required to do this extra experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 458, 917, 476]]<|/det|>
method of changing the variable .........................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 777, 89]]<|/det|>
In this experiment you will investigate the position of the image in a plane mirror.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, using the separate ray-trace sheet provided. You may refer to Fig. 3.1 for guidance.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 152, 806, 660]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 682, 532, 700]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 72, 180, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
Draw a line \(10\mathrm{cm}\) long near the middle of the ray-trace sheet. Label the line \(\mathbf{MR}\). Draw a normal to this line that passes through the centre of \(\mathbf{MR}\). Label the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\). Label the point at which \(\mathbf{NL}\) crosses \(\mathbf{MR}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{B}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 102, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 133, 181, 151]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 133, 920, 166]]<|/det|>
Draw a line \(7.0 \text{cm}\) long from \(\mathbf{B}\) at an angle of incidence \(i = 30^\circ\) to the normal below \(\mathbf{MR}\) and to the left of the normal. Label the end of this line \(\mathbf{A}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 149, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 180, 180, 198]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 180, 640, 198]]<|/det|>
Place a pin \(\mathsf{P}_1\) on line \(\mathbf{AB}\) at a distance \(6.0 \text{cm}\) from \(\mathbf{B}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 210, 512, 228]]<|/det|>
Place a pin \(\mathsf{P}_2\) on line \(\mathbf{AB}\) close to \(\mathbf{MR}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 211, 920, 229]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 241, 146, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 241, 180, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 241, 707, 260]]<|/det|>
Place the reflecting face of the mirror vertically on the line \(\mathbf{MR}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 272, 890, 291]]<|/det|>
View the images of pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) from the direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 303, 920, 337]]<|/det|>
Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) some distance apart so that pin \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_2\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) all appear exactly behind pin \(\mathsf{P}_4\). Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 350, 885, 368]]<|/det|>
Remove the pins and the mirror and draw the line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 365, 920, 384]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 396, 180, 415]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 396, 688, 415]]<|/det|>
Continue the line until it extends at least \(7.0 \text{cm}\) beyond \(\mathbf{MR}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 397, 920, 415]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 427, 144, 445]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 427, 608, 445]]<|/det|>
Replace pin \(\mathsf{P}_1\) on line \(\mathbf{AB}\) at a distance \(6.0 \text{cm}\) from \(\mathbf{B}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 458, 613, 477]]<|/det|>
Place pin \(\mathsf{P}_2\) \(1.0 \text{cm}\) to the right of its position in part (a).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 489, 390, 508]]<|/det|>
Repeat the steps in part (b).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 520, 732, 539]]<|/det|>
Label with the letter \(\mathbf{Y}\) the point where the two lines cross beyond \(\mathbf{MR}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 552, 181, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 552, 920, 585]]<|/det|>
Draw a line from \(\mathsf{P}_1\) to \(\mathbf{MR}\) that meets \(\mathbf{MR}\) at a right angle. Measure and record the length \(a\) of this line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[578, 598, 920, 616]]<|/det|>
<form>a = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 629, 181, 647]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 629, 920, 662]]<|/det|>
Draw a line from the point labelled \(\mathbf{Y}\) to \(\mathbf{MR}\) that meets \(\mathbf{MR}\) at a right angle. Measure and record the length \(b\) of this line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[576, 675, 920, 693]]<|/det|>
<form>b = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 183, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Replace the mirror on \(\mathbf{MR}\). Place pin \(\mathsf{P}_1\) on the normal at a distance \(6.0 \text{cm}\) from the front of the mirror.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 117, 479, 136]]<|/det|>
View the image of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) in the mirror.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 149, 566, 168]]<|/det|>
Place pin \(\mathsf{P}_2\) on the normal behind the mirror.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 180, 920, 230]]<|/det|>
Adjust the position of \(\mathsf{P}_2\) along the normal so that the image of the bottom of the pin \(\mathsf{P}_1\) seen in the mirror and the top of pin \(\mathsf{P}_2\) seen over the mirror appear as one pin when viewed from all angles in front of the mirror.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 243, 395, 260]]<|/det|>
Label the position of \(\mathsf{P}_2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 273, 920, 292]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 303, 180, 322]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 303, 460, 322]]<|/det|>
Remove the pins and the mirror.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 335, 757, 352]]<|/det|>
Measure the distance \(x\) along the normal between \(\mathsf{P}_2\) and the mirror.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[576, 365, 920, 383]]<|/det|>
<form>x = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 396, 144, 415]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 396, 544, 415]]<|/det|>
A student carries out this experiment with care.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 412, 685, 431]]<|/det|>
Suggest a practical reason why the results may not be accurate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 504, 729, 523]]<|/det|>
**Tie your ray-trace sheet into this booklet between pages 8 and 9.**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 536, 920, 554]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the effect of the colour of the surface of a metal container on the rate of loss of heat from the container. She knows that black surfaces are better radiators of thermal energy than white surfaces and wants to investigate the effect of other colours.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 420, 151]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 165, 693, 181]]<|/det|>
metal containers each with the outer surface painted a different colour

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 182, 245, 196]]<|/det|>
a thermometer

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 198, 228, 212]]<|/det|>
a stop-watch

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 212, 297, 227]]<|/det|>
a supply of hot water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 242, 910, 258]]<|/det|>
She can also use other apparatus and materials that are usually available in a school laboratory.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 273, 920, 305]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate the effect of the colour of the surface of a metal container on the rate of loss of heat from the container. You are **not** required to carry out this investigation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 320, 218, 336]]<|/det|>
You should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 351, 125, 367]]<|/det|>
<label>*</label>

<label>*</label>
